clinical_study.brief_title: Tracking Outcomes in Pain Patients Using Fitness Devices
clinical_study.official_title: Tracking Outcomes in Pain Patients Using Fitness Devices

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

collaborator.agency: North Carolina Translational and Clinical Sciences Institute

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators are assessing the validity of fitness devices as surrogate measures of chronic pain survey outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock: The investigators are attempting to validate the usage of personal fitness trackers against the classical survey tools used. These devices are known to be of use in measuring activity and sleep in healthy patients but their use in chronic pain patients has not been assessed. This study will follow participants with chronic back pain undergoing treatment to see if changes in clinical course can be captured with these fitness devices.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in steps taken as measured by fitness devices
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will measure baseline data for 3 days to one week prior treatment, followed by one to three weeks of observation after this treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in pain scores as measured by VAS
secondary_outcome.description: Pain will be assessed by using VAS where scores range from 0 = no pain to 100 = worst possible pain. An increase in pain scores from baseline represent disease progression and decrease represent clinical response to treatment. VAS will be assessed prior to treatment and then at a followup appointment one to three weeks later.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in minutes slept as measured by fitness device
secondary_outcome.description: The investigators will measure baseline data for 3 days to one week prior treatment, followed by one to three weeks of observation after this intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in survey measures of pain
secondary_outcome.description: Conglomerate survey device of brief pain inventory, roland morris disability questionnaire, and oswestry disability index. The investigators will measure baseline survey data before the treatment and then one to three weeks after the treatment.

arm_group.description: Patients who have chronic back pain and are scheduled for an epidural injection to treat this pain

intervention.description: After evaluation by their pain physician, if the clinician offers an epidural injection for their back pain, they will be followed for this study before and after the injection.

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients with chronic back pain

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Back pain which may benefit from epidural injection
- Assenting to epidural injection for back pain
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to wear fitness tracking device
